body:
In past I have been skeptical of CalVer.

I am now in favor of it.

SemVer would not have prevented the issue. According to SemVer 2.0 definition, the introduction of Rust dependency counts as a minor change.

> What should I do if I update my own dependencies without changing the public API?
> 
> That would be considered compatible since it does not affect the public API. Software that explicitly depends on the same dependencies as your package should have their own dependency specifications and the author will notice any conflicts. Determining whether the change is a patch level or minor level modification depends on whether you updated your dependencies in order to fix a bug or introduce new functionality.

https://semver.org/#what-should-i-do-if-i-update-my-own-dependencies-without-changing-the-public-api

Update: My comment was a reply to another comment that has been removed.

@tiran: To be fair, I don't think your quote fully portrays the idea of semantic versioning:

> If you have a huge audience that will be drastically impacted by changing the behavior back to what the public API intended, then it may be best to perform a major version release, even though the fix could strictly be considered a patch release. Remember, Semantic Versioning is all about conveying meaning by how the version number changes. If these changes are important to your users, use the version number to inform them.

https://semver.org/#what-if-i-inadvertently-alter-the-public-api-in-a-way-that-is-not-compliant-with-the-version-number-change-ie-the-code-incorrectly-introduces-a-major-breaking-change-in-a-patch-release

----

Anyhow - @alex and @reaperhulk seem to have strong opinions here, they have probably heard all the majors arguments, let's focus on something a bit more productive: It seems like quite a few people expect versions that look like they could be SemVer to actually be SemVer. Whether that is justified or not, a scheme that is less likely to be confused with SemVer sounds like a pragmatic and useful improvement to me. I personally like to just bump major versions quite liberally, but CalVer is an alternative as well :-)

Notwithstanding the fact that the comment was deleted, I figured I'd write a few words on SemVer:

The SemVer doc itself is pretty clear that breaking changes are with respect to a documented API, it's not clear "build environment changes" qualify. I think it's a pretty reasonable (though certainly not definitive) that they are not changes to an API in any sense, so you don't need to bump a major version. (Now, I have my doubts with respect to the idea of breaking changes from a documented API, in light of observations such as Hyrum's law. This is why the cryptography test suite actually runs the tests of our substantial downstreams!)

But, if they were, I think we'd actually need to bump our major version pretty regularly -- every time we drop a Python version or an OpenSSL version or a LibreSSL version. All of which happen somewhat regularly (because we support such a large and diverse set of platforms).

Now, bumping major version regularly is perhaps "fine", version numbers are free after all (note to self: find a way to charge money for these). However, if say, 1/2 of all releases as are major version bumps, people are unlikely to accord them the same respect, leading to people being upset when a major version includes a change like this. Of course, they'd be unable to complain they weren't warned, but that's hardly useful. Alert fatigue, normalization of deviance, and other psychological factors are every bit as real as strict adherence to rules when we're considering complex systems failure modes.

With that said, another valid choice I'd propose is the version scheme adhered to by Firefox, Chrome, etc: major version bumps and patch bumps only:

3.5 -> 35.0.0, if we issue a patch release it's 35.0.1, otherwise our next release is 36.0.0.

It's merits are that it's technically semver compatible, it's fairly predictable, and it communicates at least a little info on the relative age of the project.

Its demerits are that it probably won't solve the real problem here, which was that folks were surprised a major change happened at all.

I had made a comment, but then realized I was sent to another issue from a reddit thread that was specifically linked to an archived version to prevent commenting. So I removed my comment to try to follow the spirit of that move and not to add a "piled on" feeling to yall. I think you'll figure something reasonable out without my input.

@ggggggggg I know emotions can get the best of people. I personally appreciate that you considered the situation in choosing to remove the comment, so thank you for your empathy! We will definitely consider your concerns as part of our decision-making process.

For all the tooling involved (e.g. requirements files, setup.py, etc), while none of them prescribe anything more than increasing tuple separated by dots, its kinda useful if everything is on a semvaresque scheme at least

```
a ^= 12.0.0
b ^= 24.0.0
c ^= 42.0.0
```
would have value if it means that I can deploy those dependencies on a system running the same version of the OS I tested against (la a deployment scenario)

> Its demerits are that it probably won't solve the real problem here, which was that folks were surprised a major change happened at all.

People with whom I had the opportunity to speak about it were surprised because cryptography was a transitive dependency. They didn't change anything in their repositories, yet on Monday 9th CIs suddenly stopped accepting their code. Your proposition _would_ actually help here, albeit at a cost of either having projects use outdated Cryptography versions, or creating lots of unresolvable dependency conflicts between different packages (or both).

Whatever you'll come up with, making sure such updates come with the "major" bumped is the only way they won't incite backlash. _Even_ if it isn't necessarily _lege artis_ wrt. the scheme; precise procedures may work nice, but "common senseâ„¢" works even better (not that I'm accusing anyone of not having it; it's just a basic fact).

You won't be able to put everything into a tuple of numbers, Tesler's law applies here. No one follows SemVer to a T. Setting the right expectations, knowing what your users expect, and playing along that is IMO the way to go.

> version scheme adhered to by Firefox, Chrome

TIL: the scheme Chrome uses isn't based on CalVer. I wonder where I got that misconception from :smile:.

> Your proposition would actually help here, albeit at a cost of either having projects using outdated Cryptography versions, or creating lots of unresolvable dependency conflicts between different projects (or both).

This would be a substantial negative.

I think it's also worth noting that currently a lot of our dependents don't have _any_ upper version bound pin:
- paramiko
- pyopenssl
- twisted
- aws-encryption-sdk-python
- aws-dynamodb-encrytion-python
- certbot
- josepy
- acme

This means that _no_ version scheme would have prevented unexpected updates beyond a boundary.

> I think it's also worth noting that currently a lot of our dependents don't have any upper version bound pin:

But if you'd bump major, that wouldn't necessarily be _your_ problem then, innit :wink:? In that case, I would consider you extremely kind and helpful if you'd even _passingly_ tried to notify the maintainers / users of these libraries about the upcoming major - as far as I'd be concerned you'd do 120% of what you should, the rest is on the maintainers of each of the projects you mentioned.

I'm not everyone, but I reckon the distribution of sensible people would be in your favor.

FWIW I wouldn't like people bashing on paramiko maintainer, dude has already said that he's burnt out, and I suspect the backlash would have landed on him.

issue.title: Cryptography 3.3 LTS release without Rust bindings

repository.name: cryptography
repository.description: cryptography is a package designed to expose cryptographic primitives and recipes to Python developers.

issue.body:
@kaniini proposed the creation of a PyCA Cryptography LTS release branch. The LTS branch would give users more time to adjust their infrastructure for Rust requirements. Alpine and musl libc maintainers might even get manymusl binary wheels ready in time. I support their proposal and would be interested to assist with and use a LTS release in RHEL 8 and CentOS.

To reduce maintenance overhead and to set user expectations, a long term support branch should be clearly scoped. Therefore I propose

* LTS is based on 3.3.x branch (no Rust dependency)
* only updates for security issues (implies that bug must get a CVE).
* EOL on 2021-12-31. No further updates after EOL date
* supports for currently supported OpenSSL API/ABI. That implies compatibility patches for upcoming OpenSSL 3.0.0 will not be backported.
* feature updates are out of scope
* source-only releases, so you don't have to release a new LTS when OpenSSL does a security update. Users can use binary wheels of latest update.

This proposal should keep the workload small and cover majority of users.

10 months until EOL should be sufficient for majority of users to get Rust infrastructure in place. The next stable Debian 11 (Bullseye) should be released roughly half a year before the EOL date. Latest Alpine, CentOS 8, Fedora, and Ubuntu already have recent enough Rust.

body:
> People with whom I had the opportunity to speak about it were surprised because cryptography was a transitive dependency. They didn't change anything in their repositories, yet on Monday 9th CIs suddenly stopped accepting their code.

As a maintainer of some wsgi software, almost no-one seems to actually pin dependencies properly. Most transitive dependencies are un-versioned and the same people would still have complained. Secondly, most people don't pay attention to the versioning scheme used by projects, and thus if the do pin, the pins are likely wrong (as is the reason why this ticket even exists in the first place)

> As a maintainer of some wsgi software, almost no-one seems to actually pin dependencies properly. Most transitive dependencies are un-versioned and the same people would still have complained.
 
 How do you know that? (edit: I'm not trying to argue against your point, I'm genuinely curious)

@bertjwregeer would the conclusion for this be then, that cryptography shouldn't actually bump major in case of disruptive changes?

I guess one could use your arguments against any semantic-esque version bumps.
